moves.1. e4: Again, I am annotating from a game hiredgun112 played - please take your time to observe and comment.
moves.5. Qxh7: I think that Black is actually more developed, despite losing three pawns - don't you?
moves.8. Ng5: Here we have Bxf7+ winning the pawn.
moves.10. Qxf7+: The queen is immune due to the knight on g5.
moves.11. Qg7: Preparing Nf7+ followed by Qh8+ winning the rook.
moves.12... Ke8: The only move, falling to the skewer.
moves.13... Qe6:
Again, overlooking Qh8+.

EDIT: (27/12/14) This actually threatens mate - not 14. Qh8+? Kd7 15. Qxa8 Qxe4+ 26. Kf1 Qe2+ 27. Kg2 Qe1# and that is mate.
moves.14. Qh8+:
Winning the rook.

EDIT: (27/12/14) A blunder.
moves.15. Qxa8: Is white better, eleven points ahead, or is black winning? We have here 15. ... Qxe4+ 16. Kf1 Qe2+ 17. Kg1 Qe1# - so black is winning.
moves.16... Be2+: No! - wrong move, the best to be Qe2+, following mate. This loses the game (probably).
moves.17. Kg1: Ke1 fails to mate from 17. Ke1 Bd3+ 18. Kd1 Qe2#.
moves.17... Bd1 18. h3: Preventing mate by Qe1 which should have happened before.
moves.19... Qf4+: Check. The best move is actually Kg1 not the obvious 20. g3?? which fails to
moves.20... Qxf2#: Qxf2# - wonderful checkmate - so the moral is, greedily grabbing pieces and pawns may not win the game for you. Well played both sides - @oodle3.
